EPISTLE XIV.

This epistle is addressed by Horace to his steward in the country, showing him the folly of preferring a life in the city to one in the country. He says this preference arises from in- constancy of mind, and a love of change.

EPISTLE XV.

Antonius Musa, physician to Augustus, had recommended the cold bath to Horace, who practised cold bathing in Clusium and Gabii. But finding the winter too severe, he resolved to go to some warmer climate and try sea-bathing. For this rea- son he writes to his friend Numenius Vala, who had been using the baths at Velia and salernum, to give him some account of the climate, people, accommodations, &c- The beginning of this epistle is very much transposed and confused. We must look as far as the twenty-ibuith verse before we can get the natural arrangement of the thoughts.
